abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Basic Education
            Expansion Project for Republic of Yemen were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: strong focus on a single development objective is
            instrumental in achieving substantial changes in development
            trends. In keeping a clear focus on girls basic education in
            rural areas, the project not only surpassed its original
            development objectives in the target governorates, but also
            catalyzed additional support to basic education at the
            national level from the government, local communities and
            donors. Simple and flexible implementation arrangements with
            an emphasis on strengthening the capacity of government
            agencies proved to be effective in achieving project goals,
            and ensuring ownership. In a context of weak capacity,
            flexible implementation plans allow for corrective measures
            with a main focus on achieving development objectives.
            Community involvement in the definition of educational needs
            is critical to ensure girls enrolment. Community
            participation in the school site selection and construction
            contributed to developing ownership. Community Participation
            Unit (CPU) work with communities was instrumental in raising
            awareness and mobilizing communities for girls education.
